content.body: My understanding at the moment is that a module block corresponds to a `Module` instance, so locally it will only initialize once. But, every time a `Module` gets serialized and deserialized, it emerges as a new `Module` instance on the far side. The only parts of the module instance that are serialized are the `source` and `importMeta`, to the extent that `importMeta` is serializable, and the module instance is not memoized by the receiver.
content.formatted_body: My understanding at the moment is that a module block corresponds to a Module instance, so locally it will only initialize once. But, every time a Module gets serialized and deserialized, it emerges as a new Module instance on the far side. The only parts of the module instance that are serialized are the source and importMeta, to the extent that importMeta is serializable, and the module instance is not memoized by the receiver.

My understanding at the moment is that a module block corresponds to a Module instance, so locally it will only initialize once. But, every time a Module gets serialized and deserialized, it emerges as a new Module instance on the far side. The only parts of the module instance that are serialized are the source and importMeta, to the extent that importMeta is serializable, and the module instance is not memoized by the receiver.

content.body: The new `Module` instance would inherit the receiver execution environment’s import hook.
content.formatted_body: The new Module instance would inherit the receiver execution environment’s import hook.

content.body: The module instance also has the [[Context]] internal slot that binds it to the original realm, so the namespace’s objects are guaranteed to be from the originating realm.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: The module instance also has the [[Context]] internal slot that binds it to the original realm, so the namespace’s objects are guaranteed to be from the originating realm.

content.body: If we’re talking about same-origin `<iframe>` realms, still once because single identity.
content.formatted_body: If we’re talking about same-origin <iframe> realms, still once because single identity.

content.body: If we’re talking about shadow realms, once per transit.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: If we’re talking about shadow realms, once per transit.

content.body: Though with shadow realms, assuming Static Module Records are treated as immutable after construction, transmitting between shadow realms or even between threads of the same process can be optimized. You still get fresh instances of the `Module` object, though.
content.formatted_body: Though with shadow realms, assuming Static Module Records are treated as immutable after construction, transmitting between shadow realms or even between threads of the same process can be optimized. You still get fresh instances of the Module object, though.

content.body: And the reasoning for module fragments is that every module fragment has a unique `ModuleSource` consisting of the fragment and all the fragments it transitively depends upon, so each fragment is effectively equivalent to a single module block.
content.formatted_body: And the reasoning for module fragments is that every module fragment has a unique ModuleSource consisting of the fragment and all the fragments it transitively depends upon, so each fragment is effectively equivalent to a single module block.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: And the reasoning for module fragments is that every module fragment has a unique `ModuleSource` consisting of the fragment and all the fragments it transitively depends upon, so each fragment is effectively equivalent to a single module block.

And the reasoning for module fragments is that every module fragment has a unique ModuleSource consisting of the fragment and all the fragments it transitively depends upon, so each fragment is effectively equivalent to a single module block.

content.body: I think there are still open questions about the local semantics, like whether each evaluation of a module fragment produces a new `Module` instance, thus a new identity, thus a new namespace instance.

content.body: I suspect that’s the only reasonable answer, since module instances are superficially mutable. Having a singleton would create a covert communication channel.
